metadata.case_name: M/s Gotan Lime Syndicate v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: The appellant, M/s Gotan Lime Syndicate, is a registered firm carrying on the business of manufacturing lime from limestone.
By indenture dated March 4, 1949, the assessee was granted the right to excavate limestone in certain area at Gotan and Tunkaliyan, subject to conditions; lease expired on July 14, 1952.

Lease extended from time to time; last extension by letter dated December 17, 1952, up to March 31, 1953 or till finalisation of proposals for leasing, whichever shorter, with no claim after vacating.

By letter dated December 1, 1953, Government adopted new policy: divide limestone quarries in Jodhpur Division into blocks of 5 sq. miles, dead rent Rs.10 per acre, royalty Re.1 per md., lease 5 years renewable 5 years, min 10 max 30 sq. miles.

On October 4, 1954, Government sanctioned leasing 15 sq. miles to assessee; arrears from 30-7-52 to new lease date to be paid at Rs.96,000 per year as dead rent for 15 sq. miles at Rs.10/acre, agreed before Chief Minister.
Assessee never executed lease but continued to work deposits; payments finalised by letter dated November 30, 1959 from Mining Engineer.
Royalty settled post-year: 1953-54: Rs.30,553; 1954-55: Rs.27,965; etc., but payable Rs.96,000 each year as per agreement.
Terms on which assessee remained in possession: Jodhpur Division Vindhyan Limestone Mining Leases Rules, 1954 and Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1955.
For assessment years 1954-55, 1955-56, 1956-57, assessee paid Rs.96,000 each to Government, claimed as revenue deduction.
Income Tax Officer disallowed as capital; AAC upheld; Tribunal allowed as revenue; High Court on reference held capital.
Reference by Tribunal under S.66(1) of Indian Income Tax Act, 1922: whether Rs.96,000 paid each year rightly allowed as revenue deduction.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the sum of Rs. 96,000 paid by the assessee during each of the relevant accounting years was rightly allowed as a revenue deduction in computing the business profits of the assessee company.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under the rules and arrangement, assessee did not get exclusive possession; got right to get lime for manufacturing; payment had direct relation to amount of lime removed.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules; Pingle Industries Ltd. v. CIT; Abdul Kayoom v. CIT distinguishable

petitioner_arguments.text: No case where royalty payment treated as capital; in Pingle, it was lumpsum, not royalty.

respondent_arguments.text: Assessee got asset/advantage of enduring nature: interest in land, right to excavate and use area, source of raw material.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd. v. Atherton; test of enduring benefit

court_reasoning.text: No exhaustive tests; each case on own facts; avoid matching cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tests from Assam Bengal Cement, Pingle, Abdul Kayoom.

court_reasoning.text: Test of Viscount Cave (enduring advantage) does not apply fully: not once-for-all payment, but yearly dead rent/royalty related to raw material extracted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No lumpsum; royalty always revenue; more taken, more paid; dead rent advance for raw material.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishable from Abdul Kayoom (speculative, no relation to quantity); Pingle (lumpsum instalments for capital asset).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payments relate to raw material, not acquisition of enduring asset per se.

court_reasoning.text: No material to treat part as premium; holds yearly Rs.96,000 as revenue expenditure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Relation to lime deposits to be got.

holdings.text: The yearly payment of Rs. 96,000/- should be treated as revenue expenditure.

precedents_cited.case_name: Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Formulated tests for revenue vs capital expenditure.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pingle Industries Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Lumpsum payment in instalments for capital asset; royalty allowed as revenue.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdul Kayoom v. Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Speculative right to fish, no relation to quantity obtained; enduring asset.

precedents_cited.case_name: British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd. v. Atherton
precedents_cited.relevance: Test: expenditure once for all for enduring benefit is capital.

precedents_cited.case_name: H.R. Rorke Ltd. v. Commissioner of Inland Revenue

precedents_cited.relevance: Annual payment for use of goodwill is revenue.
Cost of material not capital even if via forward contract for supply over years.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income Tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference by Tribunal to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Jodhpur Division Vindhyan Limestone Mining Leases Rules, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Governed terms of lease: area, security, transfer, period, conditions.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Conditions: royalty, dead rent, accounts, access, buildings, preemption, breach.

outcome.summary: Appeals accepted; question referred to High Court answered in affirmative in favour of assessee: payments are revenue expenditure.
outcome.relief_granted: Rs.96,000 per year allowed as revenue deduction.

key_quotes.text: But when an expenditure is made, not only once and for all, but with a view to bringing into existence an asset or an advantage for the enduring benefit of a trade... treating such an expenditure as properly attributable not to revenue but to capital.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test from Viscount Cave applied but distinguished.

key_quotes.text: The reason why royalty has to be allowed as revenue expenditure must be the relation which the royalty has to the raw-material which is going to be excavated or extracted. The more you take the more royalty you pay.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for treating as revenue.

key_quotes.text: Each case must depend on its own facts, and a close similarity between one case and another is not enough, because even a single significant detail may alter the entire aspect.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Approach to distinguishing revenue vs capital.
